Although I share with all of you the interest in evolutionary mechanisms th=
at lead to complex brain-like networks, I have to note that I have a slight=
ly different perspective on some aspects (such as modularity), maybe due to=
 my work with fMRI data, hippocampal models and the literature that I am fa=
miliar with.

I try to outline and explain here my main concerns. Maybe, th=
ere is some kind of bridge to connect both perspectives and maybe we can co=
me up with some new ideas.

1. Definition of modularity: To my mind it is n=
ot clear, how a module should be defined. Accoording to Kashtan (http://www=
.pnas.org/content/102/39/13773.abstract), cited by Jeff, modularity is defi=
ned as many connections within a module and less connections between module=
s. But one could also use the cytoarchitecture (e.g. brodmann areas, cell t=
ypes / wiring in the  hippocampus) as a criteria for measuring the modulari=
ty. Obviously, the definition of modules biases the search for them.

2. Em=
ergence of modularity: independent from the definition, I don't see, why ne=
twork modules should evolve in different ways like other organic structures=
. To my mind, the same principles that lead to the formation of global patt=
erns in the organism contribute also to the formation of specific brain str=
uctures (favoring to my mind the cytoarchitectural perspective). Following =
this perspective, it seem to me that different spatial locations of sensor =
and motor systems contribute already to the formation of different modules =
emerging at these systems. This raises the question: what could be a good s=
tarting organism to investigate this hypothesis? I found this article very =
interesting, as it describes a possible transition from decentralized netwo=
rks to a CNS with modules:

"Early Central Nervous System Evolution: An Era=
 of Skin Brains?"
http://www.nature.com/nrn/journal/v4/n8/abs/nrn1175.html
=

3. Self-organizing mechanisms determine the number of connections:  This r=
eview gave me a new perspective on neural networks as it convinced me how i=
mportant structural plasticity is: 
"Using theoretical models to analyse ne=
ural development"
http://www.nature.com/nrn/journal/v12/n6/abs/nrn3031.html=

(e.g. see. Fig. 6)

The main message: neurons find on their own an equilib=
rium between spiking and resting. If a neuron spikes too less, the number o=
f connections increases, if it spikes too often, connections die. This mean=
s, the number of connections is dynamically selected to make (as a side-eff=
ect) each neuron as informative as possible. (Maybe this is the way to use =
the encoding in order to constrain the number of connections, as suggested =
by Ken?)

Clearly influenced by the cited articles, my humble and unproven =
opinion is that modularity emerges as a side-effect of the fact that sensor=
s and motors already represent something like modules and that self-organiz=
ing mechanisms and mechanisms to evolve and alter global patterns contribut=
e to the elaboration of these modules.

To avoid some misunderstandings:  I=
 think, using connection cost in a fitness function is absolutely valid and=
 provides some useful insights (therefore I found Jeffs article very intere=
sting). My point is just: one has to be aware that the number of connection=
s in a network underlies some factors worth considering. :-)
